definition: A Wi-Fi frequency band with longer range and more interference than 5 GHz. Non-overlapping channels: 1, 6, 11.
A backup best practice: maintain 3 copies of data, on 2 different media types, with 1 copy stored offsite.
A Wi-Fi frequency band offering faster speeds, less interference, and shorter range than 2.4 GHz.
The newest Wi-Fi frequency band (Wi-Fi 6E/7) offering the most channels and least interference.
A family of IEEE standards for wireless networking, including a/b/g/n/ac/ax variants.
An IEEE standard for port-based network access control providing authentication for LAN/WLAN connections.
A DNS record type that maps a domain name to an IPv4 address.
A security framework that controls access to resources: Authentication verifies identity, Authorization determines access level, Accounting tracks usage.
A DNS record type that maps a domain name to an IPv6 address.
A set of rules that filters network traffic or defines permissions for files and resources.
A Microsoft directory service for Windows domain networks providing authentication, group policy, and centralized resource management.
A printer component that automatically feeds multiple pages for scanning or copying without manual placement.
Software that automatically displays or downloads advertising material, often bundled with free programs.
A symmetric encryption algorithm using 128, 192, or 256-bit keys. The standard for WPA2 wireless encryption.

fullName: Administrative, Physical, and Technical Controls Model
definition: Administrative, Physical, and Technical security controls used to protect information systems.
Apple's proprietary file system optimized for SSDs, supporting encryption, snapshots, and space sharing.
A set of protocols and tools that allows software applications to communicate with each other.
A Windows feature that assigns an IP in the 169.254.x.x range when a DHCP server is unavailable.
The file format used by Android for distributing and installing mobile applications.
A package management system used by Debian-based Linux distributions for installing and updating software.
An energy-efficient processor architecture used in mobile devices and increasingly in laptops.
A protocol that maps IP addresses to MAC addresses on a local network.
The most common motherboard form factor (12 x 9.6 inches), supporting up to 7 expansion slots.
A document defining the acceptable use of organizational IT resources by employees.
A copy of data stored separately to protect against data loss from hardware failure, malware, or deletion.
A script file (.bat) in Windows that contains a series of commands executed sequentially.
A sophisticated scam targeting businesses to defraud through compromised or spoofed business email accounts.
Authentication using unique physical characteristics such as fingerprints, facial features, or retinal patterns.
Legacy firmware that initializes hardware and boots the OS. Being replaced by UEFI.
A Windows full-disk encryption feature that protects data by encrypting entire volumes. Requires TPM or USB startup key.
A short-range wireless technology for exchanging data over short distances (typically up to 10 meters).
The BIOS/UEFI sequence for checking devices for a bootable operating system during startup.
A network of compromised computers controlled by an attacker for coordinated attacks like DDoS.
A temporary drop in voltage in an electrical power supply that can cause hardware instability.
An attack that systematically tries all possible password combinations until finding the correct one.
A Windows stop error screen displayed when the system encounters a critical error requiring a restart.
A policy allowing employees to use personal devices for work purposes, requiring security considerations.
A device that verifies network cables are properly wired, checking continuity and correct pin-outs.
An Ethernet cable supporting speeds up to 1 Gbps at 100 meters.
An Ethernet cable supporting speeds up to 10 Gbps at 55 meters.
An Ethernet cable supporting 10 Gbps at the full 100-meter distance.
An Ethernet cable supporting speeds up to 25/40 Gbps at distances up to 30 meters.
A digital document using cryptographic keys to verify the identity of a person, device, or organization.
A documented process tracking the handling and location of evidence from collection to presentation.
Integrated circuits on a motherboard managing data flow between processor, memory, and peripherals.
A Windows command-line utility that checks a disk volume for errors and attempts to repair them.
A method of IP address allocation and routing that replaces the older classful addressing system.
A network file sharing protocol (variant of SMB) that allows remote file access across networks.
A text-based interface for interacting with the OS by typing commands.
A backup strategy storing data copies on remote servers via the internet for off-site protection.
A chip that stores BIOS/UEFI settings. Powered by a coin cell battery on the motherboard.
A DNS record that creates an alias pointing one domain name to another.
Adherence to laws, regulations, and policies governing IT operations and data handling.
A lightweight, isolated application environment that shares the host OS kernel. More efficient than full VMs.
The primary processor that executes instructions and performs calculations in a computer.
A tool for attaching connectors (like RJ-45) to network cable ends.
Unwanted signal interference between adjacent wires in a cable degrading network performance.
Malware that uses system resources to mine cryptocurrency without the owner knowledge or consent.
A cloud model delivering virtual desktops to end users over the internet.
Stored data not actively being transmitted, requiring encryption for protection.
Data actively moving across a network, requiring encryption protocols like TLS.
An attack using multiple compromised systems to flood a target with traffic, making it unavailable.
A type of synchronous RAM that transfers data on both the rising and falling edges of the clock signal.
The router IP address that devices use as the access point to reach other networks.
Reorganizing fragmented data on a hard disk to improve performance. Not needed for SSDs.
A data destruction method that uses a strong magnetic field to erase data from magnetic storage media.
A protocol that automatically assigns IP addresses and network configuration to devices. Uses ports 67 (server) and 68 (client).
A password attack systematically trying words from a predefined list of likely passwords.
A backup copying all files changed since the last full backup, growing larger each day.
A standard-size RAM module used in desktop computers.
A Windows command-line tool for servicing Windows images and repairing the component store.
A digital display interface supporting high resolutions and multi-monitor daisy-chaining.
An email authentication method using digital signatures to verify the sender and message integrity.
Security tools and policies that prevent unauthorized transmission or leakage of sensitive data.
An email validation system combining SPF and DKIM to detect and prevent email spoofing.
A network segment between internal and external networks hosting public-facing services.
A hierarchical system that translates domain names to IP addresses. Uses port 53.
A device allowing a laptop to connect to multiple peripherals through a single connection.
A Windows server providing authentication and enforcing security policies across a domain.
An attack that makes a system or network unavailable by overwhelming it with traffic.
Software allowing the operating system to communicate with and control a specific hardware device.
A social engineering technique searching through discarded materials for sensitive information.
Communication mode: half-duplex allows one direction at a time; full-duplex allows simultaneous bidirectional.
A video interface that supports digital and/or analog signals. Types include DVI-D, DVI-A, and DVI-I.
A type of RAM that can detect and correct single-bit memory errors. Used in servers.
An advanced security solution that monitors endpoints for threats and provides investigation and response capabilities.
A Windows feature that encrypts individual files and folders on NTFS volumes.
Electrical disturbance from external sources that can degrade network cable performance.
A sudden flow of static electricity that can damage sensitive electronic components.
A SIM card built into a device that can be reprogrammed remotely without physical swap.
A legal contract between software publisher and user defining terms of use for the software.
Windows records of system events (System, Application, Security logs) used for troubleshooting.
A rogue wireless access point impersonating a legitimate one to intercept user traffic.
A file system optimized for flash drives and SD cards, supporting files larger than 4 GB.
The default Linux file system supporting volumes up to 1 exbibyte and files up to 16 tebibytes.
An older file system with a 4 GB maximum file size. Compatible with most operating systems.
Malware that operates entirely in memory without writing files to disk, making it harder to detect.
A security device or software that monitors and controls network traffic based on predefined rules.
A protocol for transferring files between systems. Uses ports 20 (data) and 21 (control). Unencrypted.
A complete copy of all selected data, the baseline for differential and incremental strategies.
A network device connecting two different networks or protocols, translating between them.
A hot-swappable transceiver module for fiber optic or copper networking. Replaced by SFP.
Using GPS or network methods to determine and record a mobile device geographic location.
A backup rotation scheme using daily (son), weekly (father), and monthly (grandfather) backup cycles.
A collection of settings in Active Directory that define what a system will look like and how it behaves for users.
A modern disk partitioning scheme supporting drives larger than 2 TB and up to 128 partitions.
A specialized processor designed for rendering graphics and parallel processing tasks.
A Windows command (gpupdate /force) that refreshes Group Policy settings without rebooting.
A Windows feature providing centralized management of settings in an Active Directory environment.
A visual interface that allows users to interact with the system using windows, icons, and menus.
A forced restart clearing volatile memory, typically done by holding the power button.
A fixed-size output from a hash function used to verify data integrity. Common: MD5, SHA-256.
A storage device that uses spinning magnetic platters and read/write heads.
A digital audio/video interface supporting high-definition video and multi-channel audio.
A passive heat exchanger transferring heat from a CPU or other component to surrounding air.
A power state saving the session to disk and powering off. Session restores on next boot.
A decoy system designed to attract and detect attackers, providing early warning of intrusions.
The protocol for transmitting web pages. Uses port 80. Unencrypted.
HTTP encrypted with TLS/SSL for secure web communication. Uses port 443.
A basic network device that broadcasts all traffic to every port. Replaced by switches.
A cloud environment combining public and private cloud infrastructure with orchestration between them.
Software that creates and manages virtual machines. Type 1 runs on bare metal; Type 2 runs on a host OS.
A cloud model providing virtualized computing resources (servers, storage, networking) over the internet.
A framework of policies and technologies ensuring the right users have appropriate access to resources.
A network protocol used for diagnostic and error reporting. Ping uses ICMP.
A security system that monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and generates alerts.
A protocol managing multicast group membership on IPv4 networks.
Applying a disk image with OS and applications to multiple computers for standardized setup.
An email retrieval protocol that keeps messages on the server. Uses port 143 (or 993 for secure).
A social engineering technique where an attacker pretends to be a trusted individual.
A backup copying only files changed since the last backup of any type. Less storage, complex restore.
Network-connected smart devices (thermostats, cameras, sensors) that collect and exchange data.
The network layer protocol responsible for addressing and routing packets across networks.
The file format used for distributing and installing applications on Apple iOS devices.
A Windows command displaying network configuration (IP address, subnet mask, default gateway).
A security system that monitors and actively blocks suspicious network traffic.
The fourth version of IP using 32-bit addresses (e.g., 192.168.1.1), providing about 4.3 billion addresses.
The latest version of IP using 128-bit addresses, providing virtually unlimited addresses.
A protocol that maps SCSI commands over TCP/IP networks for block-level storage access.
A small motherboard form factor (Mini-ITX: 6.7 x 6.7 inches) with 1 expansion slot.
Removing software restrictions on iOS devices to allow installation of unauthorized apps.
A network authentication protocol using tickets to verify identity. Used in Active Directory environments.
Malware that records keystrokes to capture passwords, credit card numbers, and other sensitive data.
A switch device allowing one set of keyboard, video, and mouse to control multiple computers.
A protocol that combines multiple network connections into a single logical link for increased bandwidth and redundancy.
A network covering a small geographic area such as an office or building.
A printer using laser, toner, and fuser. Steps: processing, charging, exposing, developing, transferring, fusing, cleaning.
The time delay between sending a request and receiving a response, measured in milliseconds.
A protocol for accessing and maintaining directory information services. Uses port 389.
A security principle granting users only the minimum permissions needed to perform their job functions.
Apple proprietary reversible connector used on older iPhones and iPads for charging and data transfer.
A device distributing incoming traffic across multiple servers for reliability and performance.
The hostname referring to the current device (127.0.0.1), used for testing local network services.
IP address 127.0.0.1 (IPv4) or ::1 (IPv6) used to test the TCP/IP stack on the local machine.
A compact form factor specification for expansion cards and SSDs, supporting both SATA and NVMe interfaces.
A unique hardware address assigned to a network interface card for identification on the network.
A network covering a city or large campus, larger than LAN but smaller than WAN.
An attack intercepting and possibly altering communication between two parties.
A mid-size motherboard form factor (9.6 x 9.6 inches) with up to 4 expansion slots.
A legacy disk partitioning scheme limited to 2 TB drives and 4 primary partitions.
MBR: legacy, 2TB max, 4 primary partitions. GPT: modern, 9.4 ZB max, 128 partitions, requires UEFI.
Software that manages, monitors, and secures mobile devices used in enterprise environments.
A managed security service combining EDR technology with human expertise for threat detection.
Authentication requiring two or more verification methods from different categories (something you know/have/are).
A device that modulates/demodulates signals to connect to an ISP, converting digital data to analog and vice versa.
A document detailing safe handling, storage, and disposal of hazardous materials like toner and batteries.
A Windows installer package format used for installing, maintaining, and removing software.
A testing tool measuring voltage, current, and resistance for diagnosing electrical issues.
A DNS record that specifies the mail server responsible for receiving email for a domain.
Non-volatile storage technology used in SSDs, USB drives, and memory cards.
A dedicated file storage device connected to a network, providing centralized data access to clients.
A technique that translates private IP addresses to a public IP address for internet access.
A legal contract preventing disclosure of confidential information shared between parties.
An IPv6 protocol that replaces ARP, handling address resolution and router discovery.
A legacy API for communication on local networks. Uses ports 137-139.
A command displaying active network connections, listening ports, and routing tables.
A short-range wireless technology (~4 cm) used for contactless payments and quick device pairing.
A command-line tool querying DNS servers to find IP addresses for domain names.
The primary Windows file system supporting encryption, compression, quotas, and permissions.
A protocol for synchronizing clocks across networked devices. Uses port 123.
A high-speed storage protocol designed for SSDs, connecting via PCIe for significantly faster performance than SATA.
Revoking access, recovering equipment, and disabling accounts when an employee leaves.
IT infrastructure installed on the organization's physical premises rather than in the cloud.
A password valid for only one login session or transaction, often generated by an authenticator app.
A container in Active Directory used to organize and apply Group Policy to users, groups, and computers.
A cloud model providing a platform for developing, running, and managing applications without managing infrastructure.
Security tools controlling and monitoring access for accounts with elevated permissions.
A very small network for connecting personal devices, typically within a few meters (Bluetooth).
An error detection method in RAID (RAID 5) using calculated data to rebuild if a drive fails.
A type of NAT that maps multiple private addresses to a single public IP using different port numbers.
A short Ethernet cable connecting devices to wall jacks, patch panels, or switches.
A high-speed serial expansion bus standard used for GPUs, NVMe SSDs, and expansion cards.
A lightweight version of Windows used for deployment, recovery, and troubleshooting.
An authorized simulated attack to evaluate system security and identify vulnerabilities.
A social engineering attack using fraudulent emails or messages to trick users into revealing sensitive information.
Data that can identify a specific individual, such as SSN, name, address, or biometric records.
A network diagnostic command using ICMP to test connectivity and measure round-trip time to a host.
A framework for managing digital certificates and public-key encryption to secure communications.
Network cable with fire-retardant jacket for installation in air circulation spaces in buildings.
A technology that delivers electrical power along with data over standard Ethernet cables.
An email retrieval protocol that downloads messages from the server. Uses port 110 (or 995 for secure).
A logical communication endpoint (0-65535) directing network traffic to specific services.
Redirecting network traffic from one port/IP to another, commonly configured on routers.
A diagnostic process the BIOS/UEFI runs at startup to verify hardware functionality.
A Microsoft task automation framework with a command-line shell and scripting language (.ps1 files).
Cloud infrastructure dedicated to a single organization, offering greater control and security.
A server that acts as an intermediary between clients and the internet, providing caching, filtering, and anonymity.
A component that converts AC power to DC power for computer components. Rated in watts.
Cloud services available to anyone over the internet, owned and operated by third-party providers.
A hand tool inserting wires into insulation displacement connectors on patch panels.
A standard for booting a computer from a network connection, used for remote OS installation.
Network traffic management that prioritizes certain types of data to ensure performance for critical applications.
A networking protocol providing centralized AAA management for users connecting to a network.
A storage technology combining multiple drives for redundancy and/or performance. Common levels: 0, 1, 5, 10.
Disk striping across two or more drives for performance. No redundancy  if one drive fails, all data is lost.
Disk mirroring using two drives with identical copies. Full redundancy but uses 50% of total capacity.
A combination of RAID 1 and RAID 0 (mirroring + striping). Requires 4+ drives. High performance and redundancy.
Striping with distributed parity across 3+ drives. Can survive one drive failure. Most popular RAID level.
RAID with double distributed parity across 4+ drives. Can survive two simultaneous drive failures.
Volatile system memory used for temporarily storing data and programs currently in use.
Malware that encrypts files and demands payment for the decryption key.
Process of identifying and removing ransomware, often requiring safe mode boot and anti-malware tools.
A Microsoft protocol for remote graphical connection to another computer. Uses port 3389.
A security feature allowing remote erasure of all data on a lost or stolen mobile device.
A technology using radio waves for identification and tracking via tags (passive or active).
A smaller connector with 6 positions used for telephone (POTS) and DSL connections.
The standard connector for Ethernet cables with 8 pins/contacts.
Software for remotely monitoring and managing endpoints, deploying patches, and troubleshooting.
A Windows command-line tool for reliable file copying and mirroring with resume support.
Non-volatile memory that retains data without power, typically containing firmware.
Gaining root (superuser) access on an Android device, allowing modifications beyond manufacturer restrictions.
Malware that hides deep in the OS to provide continued privileged access while evading detection.
A network device that forwards packets between different networks based on IP addresses.
A monitoring system in drives that detects and reports indicators of reliability and health.
A cloud model delivering software applications over the internet on a subscription basis.
A Windows diagnostic mode loading only essential drivers for troubleshooting system problems.
An XML-based standard for exchanging authentication data between identity providers and service providers.
A dedicated high-speed network providing block-level storage access, typically using Fibre Channel or iSCSI.
A standard interface for connecting storage devices. Supports speeds up to 6 Gbps (SATA III).
Industrial control systems used in power plants and manufacturing. Often vulnerable legacy systems.
A UEFI feature ensuring only signed, trusted software loads during boot to prevent rootkits.
A Windows command-line utility (sfc /scannow) that scans and repairs protected system files.
Windows command that scans and repairs protected system files.
A compact, hot-pluggable transceiver module for fiber optic or copper networking connections.
Looking over someone's shoulder to steal passwords or sensitive information.
A signaling protocol for initiating, maintaining, and terminating VoIP and multimedia sessions.
A contract defining expected service performance metrics between a provider and customer.
A network file sharing protocol used by Windows for accessing shared files and printers. Uses port 445.
Phishing attacks conducted via SMS text messages.
A protocol for sending email between servers. Uses port 25 (or 587 for submission).
A protocol for monitoring and managing network devices. Uses ports 161/162.

fullName: Small Outline Dual Inline Memory Module
definition: A compact RAM module designed for laptops and small form factor devices.
Manipulation techniques that exploit human psychology to gain unauthorized access to information or systems.
A documented set of step-by-step instructions for carrying out routine operations.
A targeted phishing attack directed at specific individuals or organizations.
An email authentication method that verifies the sender IP is authorized for the sending domain.

fullName: Simple Protocol for Independent Computing Environments
definition: A remote display protocol for virtual machines offering better performance than VNC.
Malware that secretly monitors user activity and collects personal information without consent.
An attack that inserts malicious SQL code into input fields to manipulate database queries.
A storage device using NAND flash memory with no moving parts. Faster and more durable than HDDs.
A cryptographic protocol for secure remote access and command execution. Uses port 22.
The name of a wireless network that identifies it to users and devices.
A deprecated encryption protocol replaced by TLS. Used for securing web communications.
An authentication method allowing users to access multiple applications with one set of credentials.
Malware designed to covertly monitor someone activities including location, messages, and calls.
A network layout where all devices connect to a central hub or switch. Most common LAN topology.
A network protocol that prevents switching loops by creating a loop-free logical topology.
A logical subdivision of an IP network, defined by a subnet mask, that segments network traffic.
A 32-bit number dividing an IP address into network and host portions.
An attack targeting less-secure elements in a supply chain to compromise the final product or service.
A device protecting electronics from voltage spikes by diverting excess electricity to ground.
A network device that forwards traffic based on MAC addresses within a LAN, operating at Layer 2.
A standard for message logging that collects log data from multiple network devices centrally. Port 514.
A Windows feature reverting system files and settings to a previous point without affecting personal files.

fullName: Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus
definition: A Cisco protocol providing separate AAA services with full encryption. Uses TCP port 49.
Following an authorized person through a secure door without presenting credentials.
A Windows utility showing running processes, performance stats, and allowing process termination.
A Windows utility that runs programs or scripts automatically at scheduled times or in response to events.
A connection-oriented transport protocol providing reliable, ordered delivery using a three-way handshake.
An unencrypted remote access protocol. Uses port 23. Replaced by SSH for security.
Using a mobile device's cellular connection to provide internet access to other devices.
A lightweight computer relying on a server for processing, used in VDI environments.
The actual data successfully transferred over a network per unit of time.
A high-speed interface combining PCIe and DisplayPort. Thunderbolt 3/4 uses USB-C connector.
A deprecated wireless encryption protocol from WPA. Replaced by AES-CCMP in WPA2.
A cryptographic protocol that provides secure communication over networks. Successor to SSL.
A network tool sending a signal through a cable, used with a tone probe to trace cables.
A temporary passcode generated by an algorithm using the current time as an input factor.
A hardware security chip that stores encryption keys and supports secure boot and BitLocker.
A command (tracert on Windows) showing the path packets take through the network to reach a destination.
Malware disguised as legitimate software that creates backdoors for unauthorized access.
A DNS record holding text data, used for SPF, DKIM, and DMARC email authentication.
A hypervisor running directly on hardware (bare-metal) without a host OS. Examples: VMware ESXi, Hyper-V.
A hypervisor running on top of a host OS. Examples: VMware Workstation, VirtualBox.
A Windows security feature that prompts for confirmation before allowing elevated privileges.
A connectionless transport protocol providing fast but unreliable delivery without error checking.
Modern firmware replacing BIOS, supporting larger drives, Secure Boot, and a graphical interface.
A protocol that allows devices to automatically discover each other and configure port forwarding. Can be a security risk.
A device providing backup battery power during outages, allowing graceful shutdown of equipment.
A standard interface for connecting peripherals. Types include USB-A, USB-B, USB-C, micro, mini.
A reversible USB connector supporting data, video, and power delivery in a compact form factor.
An all-in-one security appliance combining firewall, antivirus, content filtering, and IDS/IPS.
Technology that hosts desktop environments on a centralized server and delivers them to thin clients.
An analog video interface using a 15-pin D-sub connector. Maximum resolution of 640x480 (standard).
Malware attaching to legitimate programs, replicating when the host executes.
Phishing attacks conducted via voice phone calls.
A logical network segment that groups devices regardless of physical location, improving security and performance.
A software-based emulation of a computer system that runs on a host machine using a hypervisor.
A platform-independent remote desktop sharing system using the Remote Frame Buffer protocol.
An encrypted tunnel between devices over the internet, providing secure remote access to a private network.
A standard allowing a computer to be turned on remotely by a network message.
A network spanning a large geographic area, connecting multiple LANs. The internet is the largest WAN.
A device that allows wireless devices to connect to a wired network, extending Wi-Fi coverage.
A phishing attack specifically targeting high-level executives or important individuals.
A recovery environment providing diagnostic and repair tools for fixing boot issues.
A Microsoft protocol for remote management of Windows machines via command line.
A wireless local area network linking devices using Wi-Fi within a limited area.
A peer-to-peer Windows network where each computer manages its own security independently.
Self-replicating malware spreading across networks without user interaction.
A wireless security protocol using AES-CCMP encryption. The current minimum recommended standard.
The latest wireless security protocol offering SAE handshake and protection against offline attacks.
An advanced security solution integrating data from endpoints, networks, and cloud for comprehensive threat detection.
A web vulnerability allowing attackers to inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users.
A wireless communication protocol for home automation operating on sub-1 GHz frequencies.
A security model requiring strict identity verification for every person and device regardless of network location.
A previously unknown vulnerability exploited before the vendor releases a patch.
A low-power, short-range wireless protocol for IoT devices and home automation.
